vulnerabilities.method: $ curl -XPOST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d "{\"username\":\"rick'; update users set password=md5('password') where username = 'rick' --\", \"password\":\"foo\"}" 'http://localhost:8080/login'
vulnerabilities.description: File contains sensitive information written directly, such as usernames, passwords, keys, etc.
vulnerabilities.recomendation: Credentials must not be stored in the Git code or repository. There are ‘Secrets Management’ solutions that can be used to store secrets or use Pipeline resources.

vulnerabilities.method: sql := "select * from admins where username = '" + username "' and password = '" + hashedPassword + "' limit 1"
vulnerabilities.description: File contains sensitive information written directly, such as usernames, passwords, keys, etc.
vulnerabilities.recomendation: Credentials must not be stored in the Git code or repository. There are ‘Secrets Management’ solutions that can be used to store secrets or use Pipeline resources.

vulnerabilities.method: * Cloud server meta-data - Cloud services such as AWS provide a REST interface on http://169.254.169.254/ where important configuration and sometimes even authentication keys can be extracted
vulnerabilities.description: Credentials must not be stored in the code, an attacker could decompile the application and obtain the credential.
vulnerabilities.recomendation: There are ‘Secrets Management’ solutions that can be used to store secrets.

MD5 is a hash algorithm considered weak and can return the same result for two different contents, which can cause collisions and in extreme cases it can cause a security breach. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_resistance
vulnerabilities.recomendation: It is recommended to use some CHF (Cryptographic Hash Function), which is mathematically strong and not reversible. SHA512 would be the most recommended hash for storing the password and it is also important to adopt some type of Salt, so that the Hash is more secure.
